title: How Q&A really treats the ‘wrong’ kind of guest | NT News
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website What really happens when the ‘wrong’ kind of guest appears on Q and A February 20, 2017 9:30pm Yassmin Abdel-Magied defends Sharia Law in clash with Jacqui Lambie 00:08:52 
Yassmin Abdel-Magied defends Sharia Law in clash with Jacqui Lambie 13 Feb 2017 1 week /video/video.news.com.au/News/ You don’t need to be a young Muslim woman to suspect you are not exactly being treated with “respect”, “consideration” or “fairness” when sitting on a panel on the ABC’s Q&A. 
Indeed any guest hailing from the “wrong” kind of media organisation (IE: not Fairfax or The Guardian) is subjected to withering contempt long before they even open their mouth to speak — but you won’t see any furious petition writers rushing to their defence. 
You will, however, see them clamouring to protect Yassmin Abdel-Magied in the wake of her on-air clash with Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie last week. 
Deciding that the heated debate between the two women when discussing immigration and sharia law warrants intervention, a group of people with too much time on their hands has demanded the ABC formally apologise to Abdel-Magied, a former Youth of the Year in the Australian Muslim Achievement Awards. Muslim engineer Yassmin Abdel-Magied repeatedly clashed with Tasmanian senator Jacqui Lambie on Q&A... affording the program a good week’s worth of headlines. (Pic: ABC/Q&A) 
“We believe this episode was in significant breach of the ABC values of ‘Respect, we treat our audiences and each other with consideration and dignity’, and ‘Integrity, We act with trustworthiness, honesty and fairness’, that your organisation prides itself on,” the petition reads . 
Dignity? Oh please. It’s a TV show — and one very carefully designed to elicit heated debate, send Twitter into a meltdown and generate headlines the next day. 
Not, as Jerry Seinfeld might say, that there’s anything wrong with that. On the contrary, the team behind Q&A have done well to keep the show one of the most widely talked about programs on Australian screens for close to a decade. 
But make no mistake, it doesn’t happen by accident. The producers know what they’re doing when they serve up fresh bait each week in the form of certain panellists bound to draw the ire of both the live audience and those playing along on social media at home. 
I know, because I have been one of them. And even though I found the audience to ultimately be very supportive and receptive during my two appearances on Q&A, it’s pretty clear that’s not how it was meant to play out. Don’t forget ABC’s Q&A is a carefully considered, highly produced television show designed to entertain its viewers. (Pic: Sam Mooy) 
Perhaps there was a bit of a clue when the warm-up guy made jokes about The Daily Telegraph to the crowd as I settled into my seat only moments before we went to air. (I’m going to hazard a guess no cheap shots about Islam were made as Abdel-Magied took to the stage — and rightfully not. That would be unfair and irresponsible, right?) 
Perhaps it was a sign I was considered to be trespassing on enemy territory when host Tony Jones directed an on-air quip at me at the expense of fellow columnist Andrew Bolt, seemingly for no other reason than to see if it might inflame the audience or even encourage them to boo. (To recap: they didn’t; I simply responded that “I will take that as a comment”; and to his credit Jones apologised a few minutes later). 
Or perhaps there was a hint that my assigned role for the evening would preferably be that of the villain when in the days leading up to the show I was inundated with messages on social media berating me for being “a baddie”. Sarrah Le Marquand responds to Tony Jones’ on-air quip at the expense of fellow columnist Andrew Bolt on the ABC’s Q&A in 2014. 31280

My sin? To work for News Corp and write a column for The Daily Telegraph. 
So where are the petitions calling for the safe environment when a seemingly evil News Corp panellist or some other allegedly undesirable type is that night’s designated prey for the baying mob? 
Blatant hypocrisy notwithstanding, what exactly was it about the fiery exchange between Abdel-Magied and Lambie that prompted a handful of self-appointed moral guardians to seek to shut down debate. Was it that the two women — the horror! — dared to raise their voices? God/Allah forbid that anyone get too worked up when arguing over issues as complex as religion and human rights. 
Some of what both women say is objectionable — and some of what they say is valid — but they both have a right to be heard. 
Abdel-Magied is entitled to her view, Lambie to hers and we the audience are entitled to vehemently disagree or agree as we see fit. But we’re not entitled to start demanding those we happen to differ with be banned from participating. 
Rather than attempting to silence the “wrong” kind of people from partaking in public discussions about important issues, we need to hear from a wide range of voices. Ayaan Hirsi Ali. (Pic: News Corp) 
Not only superslick politicians who have mastered the easily-digested-by-the-likes-of Pedestrian TV sound bite, but politicians who hail from less urbane electorates and clumsily trip over their words in the face of Tony Jones’ barely concealed withering disapproval. 
We need to hear from not only social media-sanctioned Muslims such as Yasmin Abdel-Magied, but also fearless yet polarising Muslims such as Ayaan Hirsi Ali. (Who, given her outspoken views on women’s rights and her calls for Islam to reform, is someone in need of genuine protection from actual death threats and not just from differing views inside the safety of a television studio). 
Instead of decreeing who shouldn’t be allowed on shows like Q&A, those serious about values such as respect and integrity should consider directing their petition-writing efforts towards lobbying for a public platform to be extended to everyone — not just the “right” kind of people. 
Sarrah Le Marquand is the editor-in-chief of Stellar magazine and the founding editor of RendezView. More News
